title: 104_hr2925
content: The Act titled "Antitrust Health Care Advancement Act of 1996" applies the antitrust rule of reason to health care provider networks. The Antitrust Health Care Advancement Act of 1996 applies the rule of reason standard to health care provider networks, allowing for the exchange of information among providers for the purpose of establishing a network, as long as the information is not used for any other purpose. The Antitrust Health Care Advancement Act of 1996 allows for the negotiation and performance of contracts for health care services under health benefit plans within provider networks, subject to the rule of reason standard. Conduct within these networks is evaluated based on its reasonableness and impact on competition in defined markets. The term "health benefit plan" includes various types of health insurance policies and contracts, as well as arrangements under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. It also encompasses contracts for health care services under specific sections of the Social Security Act. The term "health care provider" refers to individuals or entities delivering health care services in a State, required to be licensed or certified. "Health care service" includes services eligible for payment under a health benefit plan. A "health care provider network" is an organization of health care providers. The curr_chunk describes a health care provider organization funded by members, requiring all members to provide agreed-upon services under contracts. Compensation is received for services provided. The health care provider organization funded by members requires members to provide agreed-upon services under contracts and compensates them. It also has programs to review treatment quality, efficiency, and appropriateness, as well as to monitor and control utilization of health care services. The health care provider organization has established a management program to coordinate health care services and a grievance process for patient complaints. The term "State" is defined as per the Clayton Act. Within 180 days of this Act's enactment, the Attorney General and the Federal Trade Commission will issue guidelines on enforcing section 2.
